title: How many civilian fatalities will ACLED record in the Democratic Republic of the Congo between 1 May 2016 and 31 December 2016?
preds:
http://www.newsweek.com/2017/01/06/congo-massacres-living-fear-535786.html?rx=us  ”The massacre in the village of Mayi-Moya, about 30 miles north of the town of Beni, went largely unreported; in the region around Beni, which is located in the conflict-wracked province of North Kivu, little was remarkable about the assault. Since late 2014, the area has suffered a series of attacks, largely attributed to a Ugandan rebel group known as the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF). The violence has left nearly 700 civilians dead, according to Human Rights Watch, but local sources put the figure considerably higher. "Eastern DRC has been riven by conflict since 1994, when a massive influx of Hutu refugees fled across the border from neighboring Rwanda, fearing persecution by the new Tutsi administration in that country. Among them were many of the génocidaires accused of participating in the killing of hundreds of thousands of Tutsis and moderate Hutus in the spring of 1994.Two years later, Rwanda invaded, attacking the refugee camps that had become the temporary homes for Hutu militia groups. The Rwandan forces also toppled Congo’s infamously corrupt dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko.
. . . 
"The militias never entirely disbanded, however, and the next decade saw a spiral of messy conflicts that drew in nine African states and myriad rebel groups. The war was fueled by the region’s immense natural riches. . . with the massacres in Beni continuing unabated, locals are increasingly frustrated about the inability of both the army and MONUSCO to control the violence. The ADF, they point out, is currently thought to number only a few hundred fighters.The people of Beni are also angry and afraid. . . In August, a dozen people were crushed to death in a panicked stampede after a drunken off-duty soldier fired four rounds into the air. Later that month, rioting broke out after 50 people were killed during a massacre in the Rwangoma suburb of the town.“This [ADF] conflict has been going on since 1996, but this is the worst it’s ever been,” . . . 
. . . 
"A report published earlier this year by the U.N.’s Group of Experts on the Democratic Republic of Congo alleged that elements of the military were in fact supporting the ADF by providing the rebels with arms and ammunition. In earlier reports, the U.N. group suggested army officers were benefiting from timber felled in the rebels’ jungle strongholds.Some of Beni’s residents suspect the government is using the chaos in the east as a distraction from a bitter political row over the postponement of elections until 2018. (President Joseph Kabila’s legal mandate ran out on December 19.)Others argue that Rwandan Hutus are driving the violence in the hopes of snatching land traditionally owned by the ethnic Nande group, while others say that neighboring countries are stoking the violence so they can continue to benefit from the flow of gold through ADF areas.  "The presence of an active jihadi organization has also proved a useful bargaining chip for nearby states looking to bring in foreign military aid.In a report published last March, the nonprofit Congo Research Group said it had found “extensive evidence indicating that members of the FARDC [the armed forces] have actively participated in massacres.”Many survivors of the killings speak of fighters dressed in the uniform of the national army. Others question why some of the attacks have been allowed to take place within minutes of army bases.“The soldiers are becoming rebels, and the government is not telling us the truth. They just fire in the air,” says Vivuya, echoing a common belief in the town: that the army has been ordered not to fight the rebels. "Beni’s mayor, Nyonyi Bwanakawa, denied that the group was receiving support from the government. When Newsweek visited him at his office in downtown Beni, he was surrounded in the atrium by a group of around 40 women, widows of soldiers killed by the ADF who were demanding their unpaid pensions.Bwanakawa insisted that no members of the military have taken part in the attacks, saying ADF fighters have been stealing uniforms from the soldiers they kill, leading to confusion among the public. He added that the government changed the design of its soldiers’ uniforms in August to help avoid false identification of soldiers.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This is basically background info.  Resolution of this question will be based on the ACLED count.

On Tuesday police and soldiers fired live ammunition in Kinshasa, as opposition activists burned tyres, threw stones and attacked an office of the ruling party. Violence was also reported in the southern city of Lubumbashi, where at least two deaths were reported: one protestor and a policeman who was lynched by an angry crowd.

As per consensus, low ranked Brier score posters like ulfelder, and passage of time.

Looking at the ACLED spreadsheet, the average number of events per month is 19, with an average of 2.6 fatalities per event. The current amount is 348, so we can say that only one event would be sufficient to put the result in the 350-750 band. By a Poisson distribution, the probability of no event is 1E-7.

ACLED now updated through November 26. Tally for May-November jumped to 350 with 63 deaths in November (so far). That takes A off the table. With just one month to go, the probability of more than 400 more deaths is extremely low. I have consistently used a univariate time series model selected by the 'forecast' function in R to forecast this question. Forecasts were based on monthly totals. To restrict the forecasts to non-zero values, I used the log of the observed values plus 1. It looks like the model is going to be half-wrong, in that it strongly favored A until now, and it assigned a very low probability to C. Looking under the hood a bit, it seems the model continued to predict low monthly counts throughout the forecast period, even though the observed counts were consistently higher than the predicted ones (17 per month). That makes me think that an ARIMA model may have been a better choice for this series, and perhaps for other count series like it. I'd also be interested to use the 'bsts' package to try a Bayesian time series model with an autoregressive component or a local trend.
30 fatalities reported on Nov. 21 make 350+ very likely now.
I see ACLED violence against civilian totals as 348 for 5/1/16-11/26/16.  So upping to 100% on the 350-750 range.

Updated forecast: according to ACLED (downloaded Nov 29, 2016), there have been 315 civilian casualties. Upping my forecast in the 250-750 range up way higher at this point. Will have to keep a vigilant eye on the data for this one.
315 total as of 11/19.  30 in first 19 days of November. Plus q4 increase by key perpetrators demonstrated in prior years.

Entering a high forecast, temporarily on the 350-750 bucket, to correct a low forecast. May thru Oct. 2016, about 271 deaths or about 45 / month.  2 so far in November 2016.
May to Dec total of 350, requires 79 additional deaths, or 39.5 per month.  2015-6 monthly totals seemed to decline slightly over the Aug to Jan timeframe. Month......2015......2016

feb.............48............52
mar...........42............57
apr...........500*............6
may.........129............73
june.............8,,,,,,,,,,,,,..5
july............53............32
aug...........22.............81
sept..........31.............46
oct............36.............34
nov...........27
dec...........39 *mass grave discovered
Leaving historical average forecast on 350+ buckets to cover any remaining odds.

Adjusting targets to new ACLED Data. With the November 5th data, there are 287 countable deaths. That is averaging .856 civilian fatalities per day. Based on that trend we can expect 348.67 deaths if the current rate continues (the rate hasn't changed over the past three data releases). That puts it just under 350.
Waiting for November to play out before changing forecast

Affirming mid-October forecast on basis of ACLED data now updated through 10/29. No new civilian fatalities recorded in DRC since mid-month. My mid-month update was based on the assumption that that would be the case, so my univariate time series forecast remains unchanged.

Today's ACLED update puts total for October so far at 28, for forecast period at 281. My new forecast is the updated output from a univariate exponential smoothing model selected by the 'forecast' package in R, and it assumes that the total for October will remain where it is today. If it does not, I will update the forecast early next week with the end-of-month data for October.

ACLED update through mid-October shows 12 fatalities so far this month, bringing period total to 264. I'm shifting a couple of percentage points from C to A on the persistence of a low rate, but I won't do a full update of the algorithmic time series until the month ends.

251 qualifying fatalities = an average of about 50 per month.  If we see 50 per month in Oct, Nov, and Dec, that should be about 401 total.   A few other points: in two of the last three years (2013 ad 2014), civilian fatalities in DRC in quarter 4 were significantly higher than in quarter three.  Additionally, when we look at patterns of killing by two of the largest perpetrators, ADF and FDLR, we see that in two of the past three years (2013 and 2014), ADF killings in quarter 4 have been higher than in quarter 3; and for FDLR, each year for the past three years (2013, 2014, and 2015), killings in quarter 4 have significantly exceeded killings in quarter three.  Based on this, going to increase probability in the 350-750 range to 70%.

ACLED has now updated its real-time data through the end of September, and it recorded 46 qualifying deaths last month. Using those monthly data to update my algorithmic forecast,* I get a point estimate of 301 deaths. The upper bound of the 30% CI is 349, so that suggests a 65% chance of fewer than 350 deaths. The upper bound of the 80% CI is 743, so I'm pegging the probability of more than 750 at 9%. That leaves 26% for the 350-750 bin. * I'm using the 'forecast' package in R to select a univariate time-series model derived from logged monthly fatality totals for all of ACLED's period of observation, which begins in 1997. It picked an additive exponential smoothing model again this time.

Updating my forecast based on Jay Ufelder's forecast here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/319257 And also updating my forecast based on total ACLED fatalities equal to 239 as of September 30, 2016. Need about 100 more fatalities to get to 350 threshold. DRC is averaging about 48 fatalities per month according to the criteria for this forecast. With 3 more months left, I'm betting there's a high probability DRC will cross the first threshold, but this is just averaging out per month. There could be historical reasons why violence slows during the later part of the year, so keeping my options open on the low end as well.

Total from May 1 - September 24 is 226.  That's an average of about 50 per month.  Assuming 150 for October -December, it should be somewhere around 376.  Most likely outcome is that it will fall in the 350-450 range.  However, trend in September has been down since August.  Assuming September totals (around 35) continue, that's about 331 total by December.   Also worth pointing out that the highest months were May and August, with most fatalities in May being attributed to ADF and FDLR activity, and most fatalities in August attributed to ADF.  More insight on likely ADF/FDLR trends in the next few months would shed more light here.

As the date of the non-election approaches, there is an increasingly diligent effort to rack up the number of bodies required by the middle and upper reaches of this Q.  Personally I would much rather be wrong.
Violent protests/violence against protesters this weekend - not sure how fatalities will be categorized in ACLED database.

Updating with algorithmic forecast using monthly data (logged) through August 2016. New point estimate is 266; 350 is close to the upper bound of the 35% CI, and 750 is close to the upper bound of the 75% CI.

ACLED currently counts ~200 civilians casualties since May 2016.  That's 50 per month. I'm willing to accept the rate may level off, but that's a forecast of ~400 fatalities. I'm 45% on the low end, but I'm split high too due to @ulfelder analysis of big jump in August. Those a sizable portion of that jump may be due to a duplicate event in the data (?) which would take off 21 civilian deaths in August. But still ~50 fatalities is on trend. Barring some tragedy, more than 750 seems unlikely.

Slightly updating my forecast in response to @ulfelders statistical analysis.  I am not investing in the 350-750 section for now and will wait for further numbers/articles on the situation. Deaths in the east might spike up momentarily and do not have to continue for the rest of the year or be conneted to any larger events; though reprisal attacks might spur this out of control.  I am still concerned about the (non-)election and so far I think it is rather unlikely that the number will stay below 350.  Over 750 deaths however seems like a huge jump for me. I got to rethink this though.

Updating early with partial August data because of big jump in August so far. Data downloaded today identify 73 civilian deaths in August so far, and I think the last update ended with August 19. Statistical forecast based on those data gives point estimate of 358 for forecast period, and 750 is close to the upper bound of the 40-percent CI.

Update through August 23rd-- May 1st through present has a total of 79 qualifying events with a total of 196 fatalities.  This represents an increased rate, with 32 fatalities in July and 73 in August (to date).  With a week to go until the midpoint in the timeline for this question, the extrapolated estimate for the May-December window would be around 400 fatalities.   As I believe the likelihood still remains greater for an increase as the year moves forward (due in part to the planned/proposed election cycle), I believe the chances of a total under 350 have declined.
In line with consensus, fatalities are on a downtrend.

ACLED numbers (13 August): 125. Does not include the latest attack (64 dead?)

Not changing my forecast since updating my statistical predictions last week, but here's a Reuters story discussing the politics behind the apparent diminution in violence against protesters in July and speculating on where things are headed: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-politics-idUSKCN10I0AL

and here:

ACLED now shows 109 civilian deaths since May 1. That means there would need to be an average of about 50 deaths per month for the rest of the year to get above 350, and an average of about 130 per month to get above 750. Using the 'forecast' package in R, time-series forecasting based on logged monthly counts since 1997 estimate the likelihood of more than 50 a month at about 35% and more than 130 at about 17%. I'm using those numbers, more or less, and at this point not adjusting for the "inside" view that would include information about the tensions over presidential elections.

So far 110 civilians have been killed since 1 May 2016. That makes up around 37 per month. We are forecasting a timespan of 8 months here. If the status quo continues this would lead to 296 deaths overall. I assume the situation will take a turn for the worse once the elections get delayed, but I am not sure anymore that it will surpass 750 deaths (and of course I hope it doesn't). I have been at 10% for "fewer than 350" and am raising this now. For comparision: In the first seven months of 2016 260 civilians have been killed.

If I didn't do any mistake we are currently at 106 civilian fatalities (data updated the 23rd July 2016) in 3 month. 
Which would give 106* 8/3= 282 civilian fatalities. 
It look like they will not be an election, so that might increase the civilian fatalities by year end. (I have a feeling it is either going to be over 750 or below 350)

Based on current news reporting on violence and possibilities of the election and national dialogue processes and the current average of the data with a forecast of the current trends coming to approximately 262 civilian fatalities.
Revising the low and middle parts of this forecast based on Jay Ulfelder's analysis here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/274294

Shifting slightly to 40/40/20 after checking ACLED with today's update, which runs through July 2. The total for June is now 5, which gets to 78 for the first one-quarter of the forecast period (May-June). To top 350, will will need to see an average of 45 civilian fatalities per month for the next six months. The monthly median for the past two years is 41, while the mean is 66.

Through the end of June, it appears that there are 34 events with a total of 77 fatalities.  Extrapolating to the eight month window, this would place it on pace for 308. I still believe that there is a chance for increased violence toward the end of the year, due to the election cycle (especially if it is delayed or cancelled).  I am revising my estimate downward to reflect a lower chance of a 750+ prediction.

Through June 25, the ACLED tally for June is still just 4, and 77 for what's now almost the first one-quarter of forecast period. Using 'forecast' in R, I now get a point prediction of 217 for the full period. So, I'm shifting more weight toward the lower bins.
Lowering top end prediction due to drop off in civilian casualties, upping predictions at the lower end. Will see what next week's data release says.
If the count is honest & complete
Shifting lower after looking at ACLED data.  Still some concern that may increase as expected election time nears.

Jumping in late, but starting here until I do further research...
Thanks to @ulfelder for the ACLED update.

Shifting more weight to the lower two bins based on ACLED update through June 18, which shows only 4 civilian deaths so far in June after 73 in May. I think that precipitous drop may be due, in part, to delays in reporting, but it can't all be that.
Holding steady given there's been no underlying change in the ACLED data.
Upping the high end due to analysis here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/247807

Increasing certainty, because as ulfelder  states, this year will be more lethal than usual. 73 civilian fatalities from May 1-28. Reducing odds of fewer than 350 deaths in half.

shifting on ACLED data & @ulfelder pointing out that last month was well above typical.  Seems like violence could be worse as get closer to elections in Nov, but hesitant to go too heavily into upper bin.
Shifting to 10/45/45 on count of 73 civilian fatalities from May 1-28, which provides preliminary confirmation that this period will be more lethal than usual.

Ready to raise projections if violence escalates.

But local officials have denied the police death." http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36386738

ACLED records 222 civilian fatalities in the DRC so far this year. Given we're almost halfway through the year, I'd wager the DRC will see over 350 fatalities, but given the current trajectory, It'd be a stretch to see more than 750. So, downgrading the high end, upping the low end slightly. Biggest probability is in the middle.
Forgot about this being an election year.  Whether the elections happen or not, election years are always good for the funeral biz.

A revised forecast - my last was based on all fatalities. Thanks to @milosz for pointing this out. A revised forecast takes into account that between 2012 and 2015 the average civilian fatalities was 49. However, the average for 2015 alone was 36. Between January and today, I see 176 civilian fatalities. With the ongoing pressure of the possible election  and with over 25 civilian fatalities in only three recorded events in May, I am forecasting low on -350 and high for +750

aastanley with an unbelievably low Brier score of 0.005, crunched the numbers. Casualties based on the previous months of this year will lie form low end to high in the range of 364- 833. An election year and the tendency for casualties to spike make the high end a better bet statistically. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/234286

Within the first four months of 2016 (Jan-April) ACLED has reported 333 fatalities. April was the month with the lowest fatalities recorded (and still could be adjusted) with 52. Using 52 as a low prediction and forcasting it out for 7 months, it would be approximately 364. This would be on the low end of the fatalities in this 2nd prediction section. If we forcasted out the highest of the year thus far, March with 119 fatalities, it would then be 833. This would make one think the probability is largely within the 350-750 inclusive bracket. If we look further at historical data, each year has seen at least one spike between 298-560 fatalities in one month since 2012. Additionally, if we exclude these spikes, than the average deaths per month is approximately 119.  With the contentious election decisions imminent, even taking a modest average of deaths per month, and not factoring in a spike, it still appears highly possible that there will be over 750+ fatalities. I have increased the percentage in the 750+ because of the trend of spikes in fatalities and the current election issues.

Adjusting a bit on the latest ACLED release. So far this year I see a downsloped trendline in civilian casualties. On purely the number for just this year, I'm projecting about 58 deaths for the rest of the year. This doesn't capture any possible massacres of course, which occur once every few years, but I think assigning a 43% for -350 and a 37% for 350-750 seems appropriate to me, on purely the historic data alone. Will monitor events (and new data releases) and will adjust accordingly.

@ulfelder's information on how the bins were set.  Because of the elections and maneuvering that is currently occurring, seems likely that the total will be above the base rate.  Have not gone heavily into the upper bin yet because that would be quite high compared to recent ACLED civilian death tallies - may need to go there though.

Starting from the base rate of 290 (next eight months at rate of past four), I ask myself two questions: 1. Will we have some kind of isolated disaster, like the 2015 mass killing of 400+ people?
2. Will this election year be especially violent? If (2) happens, I think we'll get over 350 (80%) but would be surprised if we got over 700 (8%). If (1) and (2) happen, I think our chance of getting over 350 goes to 100% and the chance of getting over 700 goes to 20%. I don't know how often these outlier mass killings take place, but I'll guess one year in four (given my cached knowledge of Congo). And most forecasters seem to think election violence is likely (say, 70%). That gives 17.5% (1 and 2) and 52.5% (just 1), with about 5% (just 2) and the rest at "no violence, under 350". And... hm, I'm making up a lot of numbers. I'll slide my prediction a few points in the direction of the base rate and leave it at that.

I've redone the Monte Carlo simulations, this time including the fatalities (civilians, protestors, and rioters) for all 4000+ days in the past ten years. This of course will capture some of the huge one-day fatality rates, such as the Christmas Day 2008 massacre (815 deaths reported) etc. These are effectively black swan events, and there's only a handful of them, but there are several days with fatalities of a hundred, and altogether their random inclusion does throw more simulations towards the higher bins. I've readjusted my base rate to reflect these new proportions.

http://qz.com/677456/a-soccer-loving-millionaire-wants-to-president-in-dr-congo-but-so-fast/ Rumors of an American company involved in militia developement for Katumbi, and reports of violent anti-Kabila protests in Lubumbashi, DRC's 2nd largest city and home of Katumbi may indicate increased violence as the election plays out.

I decied to moderate my forecast a tiny bit based on the informations about the three year-baserate provided by @ulfelder at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/228363. Also, see the comment by @Milosz below mine. Instead of looking at the past three years I decided to only look at the last year in my initial forecast, but went qualitative from there on. I believe that this will be no "ordinary" year and that a base-rate might not provide sufficent information in this case, but it's nonetheless a good reason to adjust the forecast.

Not sure why the consensus is so high on this. For my base rate, I've taken the civilian (and protestors & rioters, for good measure) fatalities per day (many days have zero fatalities, of course) for DRC for 2016, and ran a series of Monte Carlo simulations for the next eight months. 83% of the resultant fatality sums were below 350, and 17% were above 350, but none were above 750. The average was 326.23. Granted, of course, political situations are fluid, so this base rate will be adjusted per developments.

The bins for this question are based on an extrapolation of the monthly base rate from the past three years, as estimated by a hierarchical model with country-specific intercepts. The threshold between the first two bins is approximately 8 times the estimated base rate (for the eight months in the forecast window), while the threshold between the second and third bins is approximately 8 times the upper bound of the 80-percent confidence interval for that estimated base rate. So, if you thought that approach to estimating the base rate was a sound one and wanted to make a base-rate forecast, you would go with something like 50/40/10. I am tilting harder toward the higher bins with the expectation that conflict over the elections that are supposed to occur this year are only going to intensify, producing attacks on civilians in various directions (e.g., state security forces on protesters, partisan factions on partisan factions, opportunistic rebels on "soft targets"). I think I overshot in my initial forecast and am hedging back toward the base rate a bit, to 20/45/35.

The recent fatality breakdown by month, according to the ACLED definitions shown using their annual and monthly data, are: 2014- 602 civilian fatalities (380 events)
2015- 956 (249 events, with one event accounting for 420 deaths) 12/15- 39 civilian fatalities (15 events)
01/16- 29 (19 events)
02/16- 52 (19 events)
03/16- 57 (36 events)
04/16- 6 (16 events) reported and logged through May 4th 2016- 144 YTD  (on pace for over 430 annualized, or 290 over eight months) Given the political disruption around the end of President Kabila's second term and uncertainty for a 2016 election, the number of violent events could increase (as happened in Kabila's previous election year).  Adding to the risk of fatalities and conflicts would be to trend of neighboring countries ignoring or abolishing term limits. http://www.undispatch.com/elections-in-the-democratic-republic-of-congo-could-mean-trouble/ While the monthly information has been below 2015 levels, and the 1125 annual fatality levels (given that the window in question is only eight months), continuing conflict and uncertainty about a relatively straightforward and peaceful transition may keep the risk of more civilian casualties high. EDIT: Updated to 5-55-40, to correct for eight month window, instead of 2016 annual figure.

Base rate 4 months 47 fatalities ->so around 100 in 8 months. (I didn't look at the fulldataset yet)
But it looks like the killing is going to accelerate.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-congodemocratic-killings-idUSKCN0XV2GQ

Overview:
Since the defeat of the M23 militia, violence has been greatly reduced. The offensive UN mission has been very succesful in the defeat of the M23, but there are over 30 active militias in north-eastern DR Congo, especially in the Maniema, Katanga, Sud Kivu and Nord Kivu Provinces. Amongst the biggest militias are the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) and the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF). The army of the DR Congo and  MONUSCO conducted succesful operations against both militias in 2015 and their strength has been reduced significantly. In 2015 the ADF still killed at least 130 civilians. Disarmament, Demobilization, Repatriation, Reintegration and Resettlement (DDRRR) Programs are ongoing and since 2002 around 10.000 FDLR-members laid down their weapons. The UN estimates that only 1.000-1.500 remained. Both militias nontheless continue to attack civlians. Aditionally, there are a lot of criminal, local "self-defense" forces, so called May-May-militias, that regularly attack and loot villages. Furthermore, there is ethnic violence in other parts of the country that from time to time escalates, e.g between the Luba and Pygmy. In April 2015 members of the Luba attacked a refugee camp and killed at least thirty Pygmy. Numbers:
In the first four months of 2015 145 killed civilians have been included in the "violence against civilians"-category.
Further three civilians have been killed by remote violence on 14.04.2016 in Sud-Kivu. That incident has not been included in the "violence against civilians"-category. Without any further analysis, this makes around 37 civilian deaths per month. The various militias so far are resposible for most of the deaths in the DR Kongo. If violence would maintain at the current level, this would lead to 296 deaths in the upcoming eight months. Last year (12 months instead of 8!) 956 civilians have been killed according to ACLEDs "violence against civilians"-category. 420 of them belong to a mass grave, digged by security forces of the DR Kongo on 18.03.2015. It is still unclear, what has been going on there: https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/03/18/dispatches-still-no-clarity-dr-congo-mass-grave. Without that mass grave, the number would come down to 536 in 12 months; obv. less than 750 in 8 months.  Outlook:
The upcoming election (whether it will take place in 2016 or not) will def.  lead to further clashes in other parts of the country. Violence in north-eastern DR Congo won't go down though it may also not intensify; security reforms are still not implemented and the area is rather remote. With the gov. being occupied by the protests, I see no major movement there. Especially since the army (or at least the presidential guard) has been deployed to crack down protests, I sadly see no way the DR Congo gets through this year with less than 350 killed civilians. I am not so sure about 750+ though.Then again, while there already have been protests against the government during the last year, they will definitely intensify; especially if Joseph Kabila will indeed run or the elections get postponed due to electoral-reform-issues, which have been regarded as a move to lay off the elections and seek an illegal unofficial third term.  EDIT: I changed my forecast to 0-60-40.
